newsitem.title: PORTUGAL: Direct talks Portugal copper mine, unions fail.
newsitem.headline: Direct talks Portugal copper mine, unions fail.

text.p: A further round of talks between management and unions at the Neves Corvo copper mine in southern Portugal failed to produce any breakthrough in the five-day-old strike, company officials said.

Strike leaders and management are due to meet later on Friday with representatives of the economy and labour ministries at the offices of the civil governor of nearby Beja in a further bid to break the deadlock over working hours.
"I have a lot of doubts," said Neves Corvo personnel director Raul Araujo when asked about the prospects for the Beja meeting.
Araujo said both sides had stuck to their positions in the latest round of talks which left little room for manoeuvre on settling the dispute over Sunday working.

The company, controlled by state-owned Somincor, insists that it has the legal right to institute continual working at the mine, including Sundays. Unions refuse to consider Sunday shifts other than on a voluntary basis.
The mine, Europe's largest copper mine, produces some 107,000 of copper per year but the company says it will become uncompetitive if it continues to shut down on Sundays.
